docs.lead_paragraph: The harmony that has prevailed between Republicans and Democrats since last week's elections began to break down today as the Senate's top Republican disagreed with President Clinton and the House Democratic leader on campaign financing and Medicare. When speaking in general terms, Mr. Clinton, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, and Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, all seemed to reflect the bipartisan spirit they say voters are demanding. But when the three men were asked in broadcast interviews about specific details of legislation, clear differences emerged.

headline.main: BIPARTISAN MOOD STARTING TO FADE ON POTENT ISSUES

docs.abstract: Harmony prevailing between Republicans and Democrats since November 5 elections begins to break down as Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, openly disagrees with Pres Clinton and House Democratic majority leader, Richard Gephardt, on campaign financing and Medicare; Lott accuses Clinton of being irresponsible on Medicare, misleading the American people by sleight of hand and demagoguery; says long-term problems with Medicare should be dealt with first by Administration, not by bipartisan panel as Clinton suggests; Clinton and Gephardt say Medicare's looming financial problems can be dealt with in short term with minor adjustments, such as cutting payments to doctors and hospitals; Lott voices little enthusiasm for legislation to overhaul election campaign financing, introduced by Republican Sen John McCain and Democratic Sen Russell Feingold (M)
docs.snippet: The harmony that has prevailed between Republicans and Democrats since last week's elections began to break down today as the Senate's top Republican disagreed with President Clinton and the House Democratic leader on campaign financing and Medicare....

docs.lead_paragraph: Mindful of lessons learned in the last four years, President Clinton and his aides are developing incremental proposals to fill gaps in health insurance coverage, Administration officials said. The proposals, to help provide coverage for some of the nation's 10 million uninsured children and to help pay premiums for workers who are between jobs, look more feasible now because medical costs are coming under control.

headline.main: New Approach to Overhauling Health Insurance: Step by Step

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration is moving incrementally to fill gaps in health insurance coverage rather than pursue grand scheme to redesign health-care system; weighs proposals aimed at helping provide coverage for some of nation's 10 million uninsured children and to pay premiums for workers who are between jobs; is seeking to insure that all eligible children enroll in Medicaid, ways of helping families buy private insurance for children who do not qualify; will propose legislation to control Medicaid costs, by curbing payments to doctors and hospitals; efforts to expand coverage build on new Federal law that will make health insurance more readily available to millions of people who change or lose jobs; map; graph (M)
docs.snippet: Mindful of lessons learned in the last four years, President Clinton and his aides are developing incremental proposals to fill gaps in health insurance coverage, Administration officials said.    The proposals, to help provide coverage for some of...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Governor Whitman sliced state income taxes by 30 percent, her critics predicted that a resulting freeze in state aid to schools and municipalities would send local property taxes soaring. Last week, the Governor shared some happy news with the taxpayers (and with fellow Republicans preparing for next year's elections): it hasn't happened. At a news conference in Trenton on Monday, she announced that total property tax collections had risen just 3.66 percent statewide from 1995 to 1996. The average tax increase during her term (4.2 percent) has been smaller than in those of her three predecessors: James J. Florio (5.4 percent), Thomas H. Kean (9.6) and Brendan T. Byrne (6.5).

headline.main: Behind the Good News, a Patchwork of Reasons Why Taxes Rise and Fall

docs.abstract: Gov Christine Whitman announces that total property tax collections in New Jersey have risen just 3.66 percent since her income tax cut tax cut; she does not mention that in 282 towns and cities property taxes went up more than statewide average; list; map (S)
docs.snippet: When Governor Whitman sliced state income taxes by 30 percent, her critics predicted that a resulting freeze in state aid to schools and municipalities would send local property taxes soaring. Last week, the Governor shared some happy news with the...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the article about Dr. Herbert S. Sacks and managed care (Q&A: ''A Psychiatrist Talks About Social Policy,'' Oct. 27), Dr. Sacks misses the mark regarding the importance of confidentiality and the role of the Medical Information Bureau as it pertains to the process of applying for life or disability insurance. He explains that because of cross linkage, ''upper middle-class patients . . . perhaps half of them who have coverage'' for psychotherapy ''will not use it.'' This, he reasons, is because if one were to apply for life or disability insurance and have any record of treatment for, say, depression that coverage might be denied.
docs.abstract: Michael J McNeil letter on issues raised in Oct 27 interview with Dr Herbert S Sacks, particularly question of confidentiality in regard to applying for life or disability insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Loretta Filippelli of Holtsville received her diploma in massage therapy from the New Center for Wholistic Health Education and Research and passed the state examination to become a licensed massage therapist, she never expected a college degree, too. In September the New Center became the New Center College, after the Board of Regents approved four-semester associate's degrees with a major in massage therapy. The program is the first in the nation to offer a degree in massage therapy.

headline.main: Massage Therapy Gains Sign of Acceptance

docs.abstract: Regents-approved associates degree in massage therapy at New Center College on Long Island reflects the new status earned by massage therapy and new appreciation of the physical and psychological benefits it confers; photo (M)
docs.snippet: WHEN Loretta Filippelli of Holtsville received her diploma in massage therapy from the New Center for Wholistic Health Education and Research and passed the state examination to become a licensed massage therapist, she never expected a college...

docs.lead_paragraph: A lone guard watched over the lobby at Jackson Heights Hospital in Queens, detachedly pointing the infrequent visitor to two slow elevators. Behind him, the hospital's one telephone operator sat in a small office. They were the only people on the first floor, where in room after room, green beds were empty, eerily appropriate symbols for a hospital that is closing. Upstairs, in a starkly furnished office, Dr. Muhammad N. Ali examined a handful of the patients who remained, including a diabetic woman recovering from an appendectomy. The 75-year-old woman, who spoke only Spanish, was typical of the patients Dr. Ali has seen in his six years at the hospital. Almost all live in the neighborhood, and many receive Medicaid or Medicare.

headline.main: Health Care Shift In Jackson Heights
headline.kicker: Neighbors Mourn Loss Of Hospital In Queens

docs.abstract: Jackson Heights, Queens, residents mourn planned closing of Jackson Heights Hospital by new owner, New York Hospital Care Network; small community hospital mainly serves area residents, many on Medicare or Medicaid; owner cites need to cut costs; map; graph; photos (M)
docs.snippet: A lone guard watched over the lobby at Jackson Heights Hospital in Queens, detachedly pointing the infrequent visitor to two slow elevators. Behind him, the hospital's one telephone operator sat in a small office. They were the only people on the...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE premise is simple. America is a nation of breaking-down parts. As we age, so do our joints, our backs and our bladders. So enter a superstore that sells items ranging from bedpans to support hose, a superstore owned by a hospital. Welcome to Homecare America in West Islip, where a registered nurse waits on shoppers along with the cashier and where parking for the handicapped is as plentiful as regular parking.

headline.main: As Home Health Care Grows, So Does a New Business

docs.abstract: Homecare America, a superstore operated by Good Samaritan Medical Center in West Islip, LI, sells all the equipment the sick, injured and handicapped can benefit from at home, from bedpans to support hose; other hospitals are expected to offer similar retail operations as they discharge patients earlier under pressure from insurance companies; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kirsten Elizabeth Turchik, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James B. Turchik of Syracuse, was married yesterday to William Odell Russell 3d, the son of Linda W. Russell of Washington and Mr. Russell Jr. of Dallas. The Rev. Stephen B. Swann performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Cathedral in Syracuse. Mrs. Russell, 25, is a marketing specialist in the Washington office of Johnson & Higgins, the insurance brokerage company. She graduated from Drew University.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHAT happened to the anger, the boiling discontent, the hunger for change? How did the country end up with a split-the-difference Government after four years of a Great Upheaval that destroyed a Republican President in 1992, shattered a Democratic House in 1994 and upended 60 years of social welfare policy in 1995? This was supposed to be the era of the big political crack-up. Of a conservative realignment. Maybe even of an emerging third party. Yet here we are, at the end of it all: divided government, again. A President who hugs the center tighter and tighter, having campaigned on appeals for school uniforms and the V-chip, the protection of Medicare and increased family and medical leave. A chastened -- and much narrower -- Republican House majority that spent much of this campaign running away from its revolutionary image. An electorate whose dominant image was an army of soccer moms driving to the polls in their mini-vans: pick up the kids, drop off the dry cleaning, move the Government to the center again.
docs.abstract: Robin Toner article on 1996 elections notes that country has ended up with divided government again despite all the talk about voters' hunger for change; contends that politicians may have overestimated all along how much change voters really wanted; maintains that 1996 elections may turn out to have been less an end to national upheaval than mid-course correction (M)
docs.snippet: WHAT happened to the anger, the boiling discontent, the hunger for change? How did the country end up with a split-the-difference Government after four years of a Great Upheaval that destroyed a Republican President in 1992, shattered a Democratic...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the latest strong objection by a state to a deal between nonprofit and for-profit health care companies, the California Attorney General yesterday accused the directors of a big San Diego hospital chain of undervaluing their business by $100 million to $200 million in a joint venture with the Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corporation. The Attorney General, Daniel E. Lungren, threatened in a letter to Sharp Healthcare to hold the Sharp directors ''personally liable'' for that amount. He said he would open an investigation of the Sharp-Columbia deal. California law requires that the sale proceeds of a nonprofit health corporation be turned over to a charitable foundation to serve public health needs.

headline.main: California Challenges Deal on Nonprofit Hospital

docs.abstract: California Atty Gen Daniel E Lungren, in latest strong objection by a state to a deal between nonprofit and for-profit health-care companies, accuses directors of big San Diego hospital chain of undervaluing their business by $100 million to $200 million in joint venture with Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corp; threatens in letter to Sharp Healthcare to hold Sharp directors 'personally liable' for amount, and says he will open investigation of Sharp-Columbia deal (M)
